dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: ...but, like, seriously, what's the big deal? So people are, um, living somewhere, who cares?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...but, like, seriously, what's the big deal? So people are, um, living somewhere, who cares?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, wait. It's not just "living somewhere." We're talking about these "rubber apartments" in Astana. Deputy Prime Minister Zhumangarin, he just brought it up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, wait. It's not just living somewhere. We're talking about these rubber apartments in Astana. Deputy Prime Minister Zhumangarin, he just brought it up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of National Economy Serik Zhumangarin spoke about so-called "rubber apartments" in Astana, where a large number of people are illegally registered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: "Rubber apartments"? Sounds like something out of a bad sci-fi movie. What even is that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Rubber apartments? Sounds like something out of a bad sci-fi movie. What even is that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: It's where, um, a huge number of people are illegally registered at a single address. Like, fraudulently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's where, um, a huge number of people are illegally registered at a single address. Like, fraudulently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of National Economy Serik Zhumangarin spoke about so-called "rubber apartments" in Astana, where a large number of people are illegally registered. According to him, authorities intend to limit the number of people who can be registered at a single residential address after cases of mass fraudulent registration were uncovered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And... this is a problem because? Are they having too many pizza deliveries or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And... this is a problem because? Are they having too many pizza deliveries or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: It's a huge problem for authorities, for one. Zhumangarin said they found one address with 3,450 registered residents.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a huge problem for authorities, for one. Zhumangarin said they found one address with three thousand, four hundred fifty registered residents.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it turns out that a recent case revealed an address with 3,450 registered residents. Can you imagine? That is impossible. So, this issue needs a systematic solution," Zhumangarin emphasized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Three thousand four hundred and fifty? At one address? That's, uh, that's impossible. No one actually lives there, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Three thousand four hundred and fifty? At one address? That's, uh, that's impossible. No one actually lives there, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's impossible. That's why they're trying to limit the number of people who can be registered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's impossible. That's why they're trying to limit the number of people who can be registered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are simply limiting the number of people who can be registered at a single address.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, like, the police can't find anyone because everyone's "registered" in some ghost apartment. Sounds like a bureaucracy problem, not a real people problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, like, the police can't find anyone because everyone's registered in some ghost apartment. Sounds like a bureaucracy problem, not a real people problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: But it is a real people problem for the low-wage workers, apparently. For them, this fraudulent registration is, uh, the only way to be officially recognized as city residents.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it is a real people problem for the low-wage workers, apparently. For them, this fraudulent registration is, uh, the only way to be officially recognized as city residents.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He pointed out that this problem primarily affects low-wage workers, for whom fraudulent registration becomes the only way to be officially recognized as city residents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's the angle. So, it's not about cramped living, it's about, uh, access to services or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's the angle. So, it's not about cramped living, it's about, uh, access to services or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. He said, like, if you have a good job, no problem. But for others, this is their only route.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. He said, like, if you have a good job, no problem. But for others, this is their only route.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have an in-demand profession, you can move here without any issues—no problems with registration or employment. This mainly concerns those engaged in low-paying jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Still, it feels a bit, I don't know, a bit petty to crack down on it. "Global practice," you said?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it feels a bit, I don't know, a bit petty to crack down on it. Global practice, you said?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Zhumangarin did say it's a "global practice" to limit registrations per address. It's about, um, preventing fraud, not stopping people from moving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Zhumangarin did say it's a global practice to limit registrations per address. It's about, um, preventing fraud, not stopping people from moving.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are simply limiting the number of people who can be registered at a single address. This is an entirely different issue—it’s a global practice," Zhumangarin noted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So they're not saying "don't come to Astana," they're just saying "don't pretend 3,000 people live in your studio apartment."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So they're not saying don't come to Astana, they're just saying don't pretend three thousand people live in your studio apartment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They're reviewing legislative amendments now, in the Mazhilis. It's a systematic solution, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They're reviewing legislative amendments now, in the Mazhilis. It's a systematic solution, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relevant legislative amendments are currently being reviewed by Mazhilis deputies. ... "So, this issue needs a systematic solution," Zhumangarin emphasized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: A systematic solution to people trying to, uh, exist in a city. Sounds... efficient.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A systematic solution to people trying to, uh, exist in a city. Sounds... efficient.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: It's because so many people are moving to the big cities, you know? It's becoming a bigger issue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's because so many people are moving to the big cities, you know? It's becoming a bigger issue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the deputy prime minister, Kazakhstan’s population is increasingly gravitating toward large cities, leading to the problem of "rubber apartments."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Well, I guess if 3,450 people are registered at one place, someone probably should, uh, do something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Well, I guess if three thousand, four hundred fifty people are registered at one place, someone probably should, uh, do something.
